member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSiteBinder
member.summary: Class responsible for runtime binding of the dynamic operations on the dynamic call site.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSiteBinder.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSiteBinder.Bind(System.Object[],System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection{System.Linq.Expressions.ParameterExpression},System.Linq.Expressions.LabelTarget)
member.summary: Performs the runtime binding of the dynamic operation on a set of arguments.
member.param: An array of arguments to the dynamic operation.
The array of instances that represent the parameters of the call site in the binding process.
A LabelTarget used to return the result of the dynamic binding.
member.returns: An Expression that performs tests on the dynamic operation arguments, and performs the dynamic operation if the tests are valid. If the tests fail on subsequent occurrences of the dynamic operation, Bind will be called again to produce a new for the new argument types.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSiteBinder.BindDelegate``1(System.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSite{``0},System.Object[])
member.summary: Provides low-level runtime binding support. Classes can override this and provide a direct delegate for the implementation of rule. This can enable saving rules to disk, having specialized rules available at runtime, or providing a different caching policy.
member.param: The CallSite the bind is being performed for.
The arguments for the binder.
member.typeparam: The target type of the CallSite.
member.returns: A new delegate which replaces the CallSite Target.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSiteBinder.CacheTarget``1(``0)
member.summary: Adds a target to the cache of known targets. The cached targets will be scanned before calling BindDelegate to produce the new rule.
member.param: The target delegate to be added to the cache.
member.typeparam: The type of target being added.

member.name: P:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSiteBinder.UpdateLabel
member.summary: Gets a label that can be used to cause the binding to be updated. It indicates that the expression's binding is no longer valid. This is typically used when the "version" of a dynamic object has changed.
member.returns: The object representing a label that can be used to trigger the binding update.

member.name: F:System.IO.MemoryMappedFiles.MemoryMappedFileRights.FullControl
member.summary: The right to exert full control over a file, and to modify access control and audit rules. This value represents the right to do anything with a file and is the combination of all rights in this enumeration.

member.name: F:System.IO.MemoryMappedFiles.MemoryMappedFileRights.Read
member.summary: The right to open and copy a file as read-only.

member.name: F:System.IO.MemoryMappedFiles.MemoryMappedFileRights.ReadExecute
member.summary: The right to open and copy a folder or file as read-only, and to run application files. This right includes the right and the right.

member.name: F:System.IO.MemoryMappedFiles.MemoryMappedFileRights.ReadPermissions
member.summary: The right to open and copy access and audit rules from a file. This does not include the right to read data, file system attributes, or extended file system attributes.

member.name: F:System.IO.MemoryMappedFiles.MemoryMappedFileRights.ReadWrite
member.summary: The right to open and copy a file, and the right to add data to a file or remove data from a file.

member.name: F:System.IO.MemoryMappedFiles.MemoryMappedFileRights.ReadWriteExecute
member.summary: The right to open and copy a file, the right to add data to a file or remove data from a file, and the right to run an application file.

member.summary: Provides a that dispatches to the dynamic virtual methods. The object can be encapsulated inside another to provide custom behavior for individual actions. This method supports the Dynamic Language Runtime infrastructure for language implementers and it is not intended to be used directly from your code.
member.param: The expression that represents to dispatch to the dynamic virtual methods.
member.returns: An object of the type.

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryBinaryOperation(System.Dynamic.BinaryOperationBinder,System.Object,System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides implementation for binary operations. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations such as addition and multiplication.
member.param: Provides information about the binary operation. The binder.Operation property returns an object. For example, for the sum = first + second statement, where first and second are derived from the DynamicObject class, binder.Operation returns ExpressionType.Add.
The right operand for the binary operation. For example, for the sum = first + second statement, where first and second are derived from the DynamicObject class, arg is equal to second.
The result of the binary operation.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryConvert(System.Dynamic.ConvertBinder,System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides implementation for type conversion operations. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations that convert an object from one type to another.
member.param: Provides information about the conversion operation. The binder.Type property provides the type to which the object must be converted. For example, for the statement (String)sampleObject in C# (CType(sampleObject, Type) in Visual Basic), where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, binder.Type returns the type. The binder.Explicit property provides information about the kind of conversion that occurs. It returns true for explicit conversion and false for implicit conversion.
The result of the type conversion operation.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryCreateInstance(System.Dynamic.CreateInstanceBinder,System.Object[],System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides the implementation for operations that initialize a new instance of a dynamic object. This method is not intended for use in C# or Visual Basic.
member.param: Provides information about the initialization operation.
The arguments that are passed to the object during initialization. For example, for the new SampleType(100) operation, where SampleType is the type derived from the class, args[0] is equal to 100.
The result of the initialization.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryDeleteIndex(System.Dynamic.DeleteIndexBinder,System.Object[])

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryGetIndex(System.Dynamic.GetIndexBinder,System.Object[],System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides the implementation for operations that get a value by index. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for indexing operations.
member.param: Provides information about the operation.

The indexes that are used in the operation. For example, for the sampleObject[3] operation in C# (sampleObject(3) in Visual Basic), where sampleObject is derived from the DynamicObject class, indexes[0] is equal to 3.
The result of the index operation.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a run-time exception is thrown.)

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryGetMember(System.Dynamic.GetMemberBinder,System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides the implementation for operations that get member values. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations such as getting a value for a property.
member.param: Provides information about the object that called the dynamic operation. The binder.Name property provides the name of the member on which the dynamic operation is performed. For example, for the Console.WriteLine(sampleObject.SampleProperty) statement, where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, binder.Name returns "SampleProperty". The binder.IgnoreCase property specifies whether the member name is case-sensitive.
The result of the get operation. For example, if the method is called for a property, you can assign the property value to result.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a run-time exception is thrown.)

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryInvoke(System.Dynamic.InvokeBinder,System.Object[],System.Object@)

member.param: Provides information about the invoke operation.
The arguments that are passed to the object during the invoke operation. For example, for the sampleObject(100) operation, where sampleObject is derived from the class, args[0] is equal to 100.
The result of the object invocation.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryInvokeMember(System.Dynamic.InvokeMemberBinder,System.Object[],System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides the implementation for operations that invoke a member. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations such as calling a method.
member.param: Provides information about the dynamic operation. The binder.Name property provides the name of the member on which the dynamic operation is performed. For example, for the statement sampleObject.SampleMethod(100), where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, binder.Name returns "SampleMethod". The binder.IgnoreCase property specifies whether the member name is case-sensitive.

The arguments that are passed to the object member during the invoke operation. For example, for the statement sampleObject.SampleMethod(100), where sampleObject is derived from the class, args[0] is equal to 100.
The result of the member invocation.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TrySetIndex(System.Dynamic.SetIndexBinder,System.Object[],System.Object)
member.summary: Provides the implementation for operations that set a value by index. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations that access objects by a specified index.
member.param: Provides information about the operation.

The indexes that are used in the operation. For example, for the sampleObject[3] = 10 operation in C# (sampleObject(3) = 10 in Visual Basic), where sampleObject is derived from the class, indexes[0] is equal to 3.

The value to set to the object that has the specified index. For example, for the sampleObject[3] = 10 operation in C# (sampleObject(3) = 10 in Visual Basic), where sampleObject is derived from the class, value is equal to 10.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TrySetMember(System.Dynamic.SetMemberBinder,System.Object)
member.summary: Provides the implementation for operations that set member values. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations such as setting a value for a property.
member.param: Provides information about the object that called the dynamic operation. The binder.Name property provides the name of the member to which the value is being assigned. For example, for the statement sampleObject.SampleProperty = "Test", where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, binder.Name returns "SampleProperty". The binder.IgnoreCase property specifies whether the member name is case-sensitive.
The value to set to the member. For example, for sampleObject.SampleProperty = "Test", where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, the value is "Test".
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryUnaryOperation(System.Dynamic.UnaryOperationBinder,System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides implementation for unary operations. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations such as negation, increment, or decrement.
member.param: Provides information about the unary operation. The binder.Operation property returns an object. For example, for the negativeNumber = -number statement, where number is derived from the DynamicObject class, binder.Operation returns "Negate".
The result of the unary operation.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)

member.summary: A thread can enter a lock recursively. Some classes may restrict this capability.

member.name: M:System.Threading.ReaderWriterLockSlim.EnterReadLock

member.summary: Tries to enter the lock in upgradeable mode.

member.summary: Tries to enter the lock in write mode.

member.name: T:System.Linq.ParallelExecutionMode
member.summary: The query execution mode is a hint that specifies how the system should handle performance trade-offs when parallelizing queries.

member.name: F:System.Linq.ParallelExecutionMode.Default
member.summary: This is the default setting. PLINQ will examine the query's structure and will only parallelize the query if will likely result in speedup. If the query structure indicates that speedup is not likely to be obtained, then PLINQ will execute the query as an ordinary LINQ to Objects query.

member.name: F:System.Linq.ParallelExecutionMode.ForceParallelism
member.summary: Parallelize the entire query, even if that means using high-overhead algorithms. Use this flag in cases where you know that parallel execution of the query will result in speedup, but PLINQ in the Default mode would execute it as sequential.

member.name: T:System.Linq.ParallelMergeOptions
member.summary: Specifies the preferred type of output merge to use in a query. In other words, it indicates how PLINQ should merge the results from the various partitions back into a single result sequence. This is a hint only, and may not be respected by the system when parallelizing all queries.

member.name: F:System.Linq.ParallelMergeOptions.AutoBuffered
member.summary: Use a merge with output buffers of a size chosen by the system. Results will accumulate into an output buffer before they are available to the consumer of the query.

member.name: F:System.Linq.ParallelMergeOptions.Default
member.summary: Use the default merge type, which is AutoBuffered.

member.name: F:System.Linq.ParallelMergeOptions.FullyBuffered
member.summary: Use a merge with full output buffers. The system will accumulate all of the results before making any of them available to the consumer of the query.

member.name: F:System.Linq.ParallelMergeOptions.NotBuffered
member.summary: Use a merge without output buffers. As soon as result elements have been computed, make that element available to the consumer of the query.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.Add
member.summary: An addition operation, such as a + b, without overflow checking, for numeric operands.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.AddAssign
member.summary: An addition compound assignment operation, such as (a += b), without overflow checking, for numeric operands.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.AddAssignChecked
member.summary: An addition compound assignment operation, such as (a += b), with overflow checking, for numeric operands.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.AddChecked
member.summary: An addition operation, such as (a + b), with overflow checking, for numeric operands.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.And
member.summary: A bitwise or logical AND operation, such as (a & b) in C# and (a And b) in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.AndAlso
member.summary: A conditional AND operation that evaluates the second operand only if the first operand evaluates to true. It corresponds to (a && b) in C# and (a AndAlso b) in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.AndAssign
member.summary: A bitwise or logical AND compound assignment operation, such as (a &= b) in C#.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.ArrayIndex
member.summary: An indexing operation in a one-dimensional array, such as array[index] in C# or array(index) in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.ArrayLength
member.summary: An operation that obtains the length of a one-dimensional array, such as array.Length.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.Assign
member.summary: An assignment operation, such as (a = b).

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.Block
member.summary: A block of expressions.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.Call
member.summary: A method call, such as in the obj.sampleMethod() expression.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.Coalesce
member.summary: A node that represents a null coalescing operation, such as (a ?? b) in C# or If(a, b) in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.Conditional
member.summary: A conditional operation, such as a > b ? a : b in C# or If(a > b, a, b) in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.Constant
member.summary: A constant value.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.Convert
member.summary: A cast or conversion operation, such as (SampleType)obj in C#or CType(obj, SampleType) in Visual Basic. For a numeric conversion, if the converted value is too large for the destination type, no exception is thrown.

member.name: F:System.Linq.Expressions.ExpressionType.ConvertChecked
member.summary: A cast or conversion operation, such as (SampleType)obj in C#or CType(obj, SampleType) in Visual Basic. For a numeric conversion, if the converted value does not fit the destination type, an exception is thrown.

p.p: Provides an internal interface for accessing the arguments of multiple tree nodes (DynamicExpression, ElementInit, MethodCallExpression, InvocationExpression, NewExpression, and InexExpression). You should not use this API. It is only public due to DLL refactoring and exists only for internal performance optimizations.

This enables two optimizations which reduce the size of expression trees. The first enables the tree nodes to hold onto an IList instead of a ReadOnlyCollection. IList saves the cost of allocating the ReadOnlyCollection for each node. The second enables creating specialized subclasses that hold onto a specific number of arguments (for example, Block2, Block3, Block4). Therefore, these nodes avoid allocating both a ReadOnlyCollection and an array for storing their elements, saving 32 bytes per node.
The expression tree nodes continue to expose the original LINQ properties of ReadOnlyCollections. The nodes do this by re-using a field for storing both the array or an element that would normally be stored in the array.
For the array case, the collection is typed to IList instead of ReadOnlyCollection. When the node is initially constructed it is an array. When the compiler accesses the members it uses this interface. Accessing array elements promotes the array to a ReadOnlyCollection.
For the object case we store the first argument in a field typed to object. When the node is initially constructed, the field holds the Expression. The compiler accesses arguments through this interface, and the accessor for the first argument uses Expression.ReturnObject to return the object that handles the Expression or ReadOnlyCollection case. When the user accesses the ReadOnlyCollection, then the object field is updated to hold directly onto the ReadOnlyCollection.
It is important that the Expressions consistently return the same ReadOnlyCollection. Otherwise, the re-writer tree walker will break. It is a breaking change from LINQ v1 to return different ReadOnlyCollections form the same Expression node. Currently users can rely on object identity to tell if the node has changed. Storing the ReadOnlyCollection in an overloaded field both reduces memory usage and maintains compatibility for the public API.

member.name: T:System.Linq.Expressions.IDynamicExpression
member.summary: Provides an internal interface for accessing the arguments of DynamicExpression tree nodes as well as CallSite and Rewriting functionality. You should not use this API. It is only public due to DLL refactoring and exists only for internal performance optimizations.

member.name: M:System.Linq.Expressions.IDynamicExpression.CreateCallSite
member.summary: Optionally creates the CallSite and returns the CallSite for the DynamicExpression’s polymorphic inline cache. You should not use this type. It is only public due to assembly refactoring, and it is used internally for performance optimizations.
member.returns: The CallSite for the DynamicExpression’s polymorphic inline cache.

member.name: P:System.Linq.Expressions.IDynamicExpression.DelegateType
member.summary: Gets the delegate type used by the CallSite, which is the type of the rules used in the dynamic expression’s polymorhphic inline cache.
member.returns: The delegate type used by the CallSite.

member.name: M:System.Linq.Expressions.IDynamicExpression.Rewrite(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression[])
member.summary: Rewrites this node replacing the dynamic expression’s arguments with the provided values. The number of args needs to match the number of the current expression. You should not use this type. It is only public due to assembly refactoring, and it is used internally for performance optimizations. This helper method allows re-writing of nodes to be independent of the specific implementation class deriving from DynamicExpression that is being used at the call site.
member.param: The arguments used to replace this node.
member.returns: The rewritten node, but if no changes were made, then returns the same node.

member.summary: Specifies the right to exert full control over a pipe, and to modify access control and audit rules. This value represents the combination of all rights in this enumeration.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.Read
member.summary: Specifies the right to read from the pipe. This right includes the , , , and rights.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.ReadAttributes
member.summary: Specifies the right to read file system attributes from a pipe. This does not include the right to read data, extended file system attributes, or access and audit rules.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.ReadData
member.summary: Specifies the right to read data from the pipe. This does not include the right to read file system attributes, extended file system attributes, or access and audit rules.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.ReadExtendedAttributes
member.summary: Specifies the right to read extended file system attributes from a pipe. This does not include the right to read data, file system attributes, or access and audit rules.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.ReadPermissions
member.summary: Specifies the right to read access and audit rules from the pipe. This does not include the right to read data, file system attributes, or extended file system attributes.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.ReadWrite
member.summary: Specifies the right to read and write from the pipe. This right includes the , , , , , , and rights.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.Synchronize
member.summary: Specifies whether the application can wait for a pipe handle to synchronize with the completion of an I/O operation.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.TakeOwnership
member.summary: Specifies the right to change the owner of a pipe. Note that owners of a pipe have full access to that resource.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.Write
member.summary: Specifies the right to write to the pipe. This right includes the , , and rights.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.WriteAttributes
member.summary: Specifies the right to write file system attributes to a pipe. This does not include the right to write data or extended file system attributes.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.WriteData
member.summary: Specifies the right to write data to a pipe. This does not include the right to write file system attributes or extended file system attributes.

member.name: F:System.IO.Pipes.PipeAccessRights.WriteExtendedAttributes
member.summary: Specifies the right to write extended file system attributes to a pipe. This does not include the right to write file attributes or data.

member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve
member.summary: Represents an elliptic curve.

member.summary: The first coefficient for an explicit curve. A for short Weierstrass, Montgomery, and Twisted Edwards curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.B
member.summary: The second coefficient for an explicit curve. B for short Weierstrass and d for Twisted Edwards curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Cofactor
member.summary: The cofactor of the curve.

member.summary: Creates a named curve using the specified friendly name of the identifier.
member.param: The friendly name of the identifier.
member.returns: An object representing the named curve.
member.exception: oidFriendlyName is null.

member.summary: Creates a named curve using the specified object.

member.name: M:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.CreateFromValue(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a named curve using the specified dotted-decimal representation of the identifier.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.CurveType
member.summary: Identifies the composition of the object.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.G
member.summary: The generator, or base point, for operations on the curve.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Hash
member.summary: The name of the hash algorithm which was used to generate the curve coefficients ( and ) from the under the ANSI X9.62 generation algorithm. Applies only to explicit curves.

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.IsCharacteristic2
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the curve type indicates an explicit characteristic 2 curve.
member.returns: true if the curve is an explicit characteristic 2 curve; false if the curve is a named characteristic 2, prime, or implicit curve.

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.IsExplicit
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the curve type indicates an explicit curve (either prime or characteristic 2).
member.returns: true if the curve is an explicit curve (either prime or characteristic 2); false if the curve is a named or implicit curve.

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.IsNamed
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the curve type indicates a named curve.
member.returns: true if the curve is a named curve; false if the curve is an implict or an explicit curve (either prime or characteristic 2).

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.IsPrime
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the curve type indicates an explicit prime curve.
member.returns: true if the curve is an explicit prime curve; false if the curve is a named prime, characteristic 2 or implicit curves.

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Oid
member.summary: Gets the identifier of a named curve.
member.returns: The identifier of a named curve.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Order
member.summary: The order of the curve. Applies only to explicit curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Polynomial
member.summary: The curve polynomial. Applies only to characteristic 2 curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Prime
member.summary: The prime specifying the base field. Applies only to prime curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Seed
member.summary: The seed value for coefficient generation under the ANSI X9.62 generation algorithm. Applies only to explicit curves.

member.name: M:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Validate
member.summary: Validates the integrity of the current curve. Throws a exception if the structure is not valid.
member.exception: The curve parameters are not valid for the current curve type.
